div.head: TO SYLVANUS,
div.p: LATELY reading the little Hi≈øtory of the Five Indian Nations, I met with a Pa≈ø≈øage in it, which I thought worth particular Notice. It is this, I ≈øuppo≈øe our Interpreters were not Poets enough to tran≈ølate the Songs, otherwi≈øe I might have gratified the Reader with a Ta≈øte of Indian Poetry.
I have enquired whether any ≈øuch Songs could be found, as I know that you are curious in ≈øuch Things; and the≈øe, which I now ≈øend to you, ≈øince came to Hand.

Maratho is named for the Originals, and Yariza, and that is all that I can tell you of them at pre≈øent, but I ≈øhall make further Enquiry. This much I can tell you now, that ≈øome que≈øtion whether Yariza compos'd her Part, or only ≈øung it. The Di≈øpute is not very material; but if there be ≈øuch a Genius, as we are told, among the Indians, I know not why the gentler Sex, may not be ≈øuppo≈øed to partake of it, e≈øpecially, on Subjects ≈øuitable to their Gentlene≈øs.
They ≈øeem to have been de≈øigned on Occa≈øion of promulging the la≈øt General Peace.

p.q: What Time is this for them? (≈øays a Critic) Why did they not come ≈øooner?

div.p: And, (if it be civil to an≈øwer one Que≈øtion by a≈øking another, but what ≈øhall one do with captious Critic's) why were they not a≈øk'd for, or enquir'd after ≈øooner? Perhaps they are come full ≈øoon, for any Thing that will be thought of them.‚ÄîPerhaps it is the Fa≈øhion of Indian Writers, to keep their Compo≈øures by them for ≈øome Time, to correct and poli≈øh; and well it were for ≈øome others, and for their Readers, that they would do likewi≈øe. Better Pieces, than they are, have lain by many more Years, before they have made their Appearance.‚Äî Ay,‚Äîbut it looks ≈øu≈øpicious, that Yariza ≈øays nothing of Prince Frederick, who was living at that Time.

There might be a Rea≈øon given for that,‚Äîher Thoughts were taken up;‚Äî≈øhe was lamenting the Death of the Queen;‚Äîadmiring the Prince≈øs,‚Äînow Prince≈øs Dowager:‚ÄîAnd is it not natural for the Female Kind, much to ≈øet by tho≈øe of their own Sex, who are highly eminent?

p.q: Very well,‚Äîbut to ≈øpeak of the young Prince, and not to mention his Father, a Prince ≈øo noble, human, beneficent, of ≈øuch Appearance and Hopes.

div.p: Alas!‚Äîthe≈øe Critics love to perplex Matters.‚ÄîI ≈øhall leave them to ob≈øerve to you, that the≈øe Songs or Odes, call them which you plea≈øe, by their Air and Accent, appear of Indian Extraction They abound with that Phra≈øeology. The Tree, the Chain, the Hou≈øe of Peace, the great Sachem for the King, the great Lake for the Ocean, Corlaer for the Governor of the Province, Manhaten for New-York, you very well know are Terms in U≈øe with them.

The Book of Peace, if they are not u≈øed ≈øo to call the Book there intended, I think it would be nothing ami≈øs to learn them to call it ≈øo; and I can not apprehend that the Tran≈ølator, granting that he found not
that Expre≈ø≈øion in the Original, but added it, is to be blamed for ≈øuch an Addition.

But ≈øuppo≈øe that the Writer of the≈øe Odes only took Hints from the Indian, and that they are far from being a clo≈øe Tran≈ølation; yet, ought we not to e≈øteem the Indian Genius, which could give ≈øuch Hints to him?

The Author of the little Hi≈øtory of the≈øe Nations, ≈øays of them, to his Excellency Governor Burnet, to whom he dedicates it; that tho' they were under the darke≈øt Ignorance, yet, a bright and noble Genius ≈øhines thro' the≈øe black Clouds.

He goes on to ≈øay, that, none of the greate≈øt Roman Heroes have di≈øcovered a greater Love to their Country, or a greater Contempt of Death, than the≈øe Barbarians have done, when Life and Liberty came in Competition.

In another Place he ≈øays, that, if Care was taken to plant in them, and cultivate that general Benevolence to Mankind, which is the true Principle of Virtue,‚Äîthey would no longe: de≈øerve the Name of Barbarians, but would become a People who≈øe Friend≈øhip might add Honour to the Briti≈øh Nation.
What Pity is it, that ≈øuch a Genius ≈øhould be ≈øunk or depraved, which, if it was reliev'd and rightly cultivated, might ≈øhine out to them, and to us, with Advantage and with Honour.
Would not ≈øuch cultivating of it, tend to the Good of the Publick, not only of this Province and tho≈øe Nations, but promote the Briti≈øh,‚Äîthe Chri≈øtian Intere≈øt?

To this might be conducive, if ≈øome Per≈øon capable of furthering ≈øuch an Intention, were encouraged to ≈øettle for ≈øome Time in tho≈øe Parts, to attain the Language, if he has it not already, and under proper Direction to in≈øtitute Schools, or, at lea≈øt, in the mean Time, one good School for Education, and to enquire for the
fitte≈øt Per≈øons to recommend to the Care and Charge of it.

If there is already a School there; for I do not pretend to be well acquainted with the pre≈øent Di≈øpo≈øition of Affairs in tho≈øe Parts, there might be another ≈øet up at a convenient Di≈øtance; and it may not be ami≈øs, to ≈øet one or two good Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øes over a ≈øeparate School of Girls. Much would depend on the Improving and Refining that Sex, to reclaim and civilize the other.

In the≈øe Schools, ≈øome of the mo≈øt Ingenious and Docile of the young Indians might be in≈øtructed in our Faith and Morals, and Language, and in our Methods of Life and Indu≈øtry, and in ≈øome of tho≈øe Arts which are mo≈øt u≈øeful.

The≈øe, that is, ≈øome of the be≈øt di≈øpo≈øed and qualified of them, might in Time be ≈øet over other Schools, for it may be thought not unfitting, that there were one, at lea≈øt, for every Nation, or rather for each of the Tribes, which are reckon'd three in every Nation.
In the mean Time, the Youths ≈øo forming, might be profitable, each in the Family which he belongs to, where he might be look'd upon as a young In≈øtructor, and frequently be ≈øo,
This, likewi≈øe, might help to prevent Teachers being ≈øent among them by another Nation, which has been done formerly, and has been found prejudicial.

Our Hi≈øtorian, Mr. Colden, tells us, pag. 69. We may ≈øtill ob≈øerve the Influence, which the French Prie≈øts had obtained over the other Nations, and to what Chri≈øtian-like Purpo≈øes they u≈øed it.

Tho≈øe other Nations, page 70, are the Onandagas, Cayugas, and Oneydoes, three of the Five; and the Purpo≈øes were ≈øpiriting them up again≈øt other Indians, Friends of Virginia, whom they made War on, and kill'd ≈øome of the People of Virginia who a≈ø≈øi≈øted tho≈øe Indians.
And p. 71. By the Influence of one of them, nam'd Milet, a Je≈øuit, on the Oneydoes, they were frequently turn'd again≈øt the Southern Indians, Friends of the Engli≈øh Southern Colonies.

The≈øe Quotations, I hope, will not ≈øeem tedious to you. This Ob≈øervation may ari≈øe from them, that ≈øince there have been, and ≈øtill are Men ≈øo indu≈øtrious, for ≈øecular Ends (at lea≈øt, ≈øuch their De≈øigns appear to us) as to compa≈øs Sea and Land, to make Pro≈øelytes; it will be becoming in us to attempt more exten≈øive Methods for enlightning the Under≈øtanding, and reforming the Way of Living of tho≈øe People, to which we are urg'd by a Variety of the be≈øt Motives.

To civilize our Friends and Neighbours; ‚Äî to ≈øtrengthen our Allies and our Alliance;‚Äî to adorn and dignify Human Nature;‚Äîto ≈øave Souls from Death; to promote the Chri≈øtian Faith, and the Divine Glory, are the Motives.

There is yet another which may incline our Hearts to the≈øe People, and that is, the great Love which they expre≈øs to Peace. Is there a Nation under Heaven, which ≈øpeaks of it in more complacent and pathetic Terms?

No Wonder, if their young Men of Genius, their Bards or Druids, like Maratho; their young Maids of fine natural Qualities, like Yariza; No Wonder, if they ≈øhould frame Songs of Peace, when the old Men, the Sachems, ≈øpeak of it with ≈øuch Pa≈ø≈øion and Rapture, that their Speech ≈øeems a poetical Language; a Kind of divine Enthu≈øia≈øm.‚Äî

What do you think, Sir, would it not be worth a Philo≈øopher's While to come from Europe, to ≈øee the≈øe Nations of Peace-Lovers, and to conver≈øe with them, and if he could purcha≈øe ≈øome Slips or Suckers of their Tree of Peace? Would it not be well done to take them back with him, and recommend them to the
European Regions? The Princes there u≈øe to be fond of foreign Rarities.‚Äî What if the precious Tree was propagated in the Gardens at Ken≈øington? What if in tho≈øe at Vienna, Marli, the Arranjuez,‚ÄîPot≈ødam?‚Äî

Not that tho≈øe Imperial and Royal Gardens, are ≈øuppo≈øed now to want Trees or Plants of ≈øuch Kind,‚Äîhappy, if they take Root and flouri≈øh,‚Äîif they be duly cultivated;‚Äî if the great Owners water them with their own Hands: Nor is that beneath their Dignity, if they look on them as their Garden's chief Ornaments, and Delight to meditate the Good of Mankind, under their Shadows: ‚Äî But, ≈øtill, ≈øuch Slips from hence might be favourably received as an exotic Curio≈øity.

I return to the Five Nations. That you may not think that I magnify their Love of Peace: Read their own Words, ≈øpeaking of the Tree of Peace, in one of their Orations, in the 3d Chap. of the Hi≈øtory.

We now plant a Tree, who≈øe Top will reach the Sun, and its Branches ≈øpread far abroad, ≈øo that it ≈øhall be ≈øeen afar off, and we ≈øhall ≈øhelter over ≈øelves under it, and live in Peace without Mole≈øtation.‚Äîp. 67. The Tree of Peace is planted ≈øo firmly that it can not be moved. p. 89. they ≈øay, That they ≈øhall Dance to the Calumet of Peace, under its Leaves, and ≈øhall remain quiet.
In like Language, they ≈øpeak of the Chain, which ≈øeems to ≈øignify with them, a League of Peace or Alliance.

Page 60. We gladly catch at, and lay hold of the Chain, which we de≈øire may be kept clean and bright like Silver. p. 67. Now we have a new Chain, a ≈øtrong and a ≈øtraight Chain that cannot be broken,‚ÄîLet us on both Sides hold the Chain fa≈øt.

Is it not a Pity that People, who ≈øeem ≈øo much to love Peace, ≈øhould not be further'd in the be≈øt Methods of pre≈øerving it inwardly in their Minds, as well as in their
outward Condition? I doubt not, but that the worthy Man, who was there formerly, did his Endeavour, and that he who is now there does the ≈øame; but what is one Man to ≈øuch Multitudes?

Should they not be more exten≈øively acquainted with the Doctrine and Precepts of the Prince of Peace, by the Knowledge and Ob≈øervance of which, they would be led into tho≈øe ≈øerene Regions, where their beloved Tree flouri≈øhes with a ≈øweet Odour for ever?

Should not Schools and Oratories be ≈øet up in ≈øundry Parts of the Indian Nations, or, at lea≈øt, as has been ≈øaid before, one or two principal Ones, from whence others might derive, as from ≈øome beneficent Springs-Head flows a Stream, which becomes a great River to refre≈øh an exten≈øive Country, and make glad the Hearts of a populous Nation?

Where are the Men, who de≈øire, like the Heroes and Law-givers of Antiquity, to re≈øcue Nations from Barbarity; like the cho≈øen Mi≈ø≈øionaries, to propagate the Divine Light, which came to enlighten the World: Is it not becoming them to appear in ≈øuch an Undertaking?

However u≈øeful one, or another might be in the immediate Parts: Do you not think, Sylvanus, that ≈øuch an Intention would require the chief Men of the Province, for Pre≈øidents and Conductors of it? Should not the leading Men of the Neighbouring Colonies, de≈øire to a≈ø≈øociate in it; the rather as the Welfare and Security of tho≈øe Colonies as well as of this, ≈øeem to have ≈øome Connexion with a right In≈øtitution of the≈øe Indians?
It is not improbable that the Briti≈øh Society, on proper Application, would further encourage it. Nor is it to be doubted, but that ≈øome in high Stations in Britain, would promote it.

The Court, the Nobles, and Gentlemen there, many of whom are of the fine≈øt Ta≈øte and Expre≈ø≈øion, in the
various Kinds of Eloquence, might, in Con≈øequence of this, in a little Time, expect from hence, finer Indian Odes, than what are now pre≈øented to them.

But if they think little of the Songs of India, (as indeed the≈øe Tran≈øeripts, at lea≈øt, are not much to be thought of, whatever Originals may be) yet, it is becoming them to advance the Cau≈øe of Chri≈øtianity; and it is not unworthy of their Care, to promote, by all proper Means, the Maintaining the Ballance of Power in America, as well as in other Parts of the World.
An Objection has been rai≈øed by ≈øome Gentlemen, not again≈øt the Expediency of this Work, but becau≈øe of the Difficulty of it.
They repre≈øent the Indians, as an untractable People, very tenacious of their own Manners and Fa≈øhions.

If ≈øuch an Attempt and Performance were very ea≈øy, there would be the le≈øs Honour in accompli≈øhing it. But neither can I imagine it ≈øo very difficult. Very wild and ≈øavage Nations have been reformed; therefore, the Indians, who are nothing ≈øo Savage, may be reformed. One or two Men, have ≈øometimes done a great deal towards civilizing the Manners of a People. What may not be done by the eminent Men of a large Province, in Conjuction? Perhaps to be a≈ø≈øi≈øted by ≈øome of their be≈øt Neighbours, and ≈øupported by a high Encouragement.

How much have ≈øome wild People, ≈øuch formerly, improved in other Countries within this Century, and ≈øome in half that Time. What need to ≈øpeak of other Nations and of ancient Ages? Mr. Colden, who≈øe Book I open again, ≈øeems to think the Indians like other People. I am fond to think, ≈øays he, that the pre≈øent State of the Indian Nations, exactly ≈øhews the mo≈øt ancient and original Condition of almo≈øt every Nation. If the Original be the ≈øame, why may there not be a like Progre≈øs, e≈øpecially in a People,
who ≈øeem to have an innate Di≈øpo≈øition to Science, and who breathe untaught Eloquence?

Then,‚Äî that Love of Liberty and Honour;‚Äî that Roman,‚Äî that Briti≈øh Spirit:‚Äî They ≈øeem naturally akin to us,‚Äî be≈øide our Alliance,‚Äî let us help our Brethren. If the rough Gem throws out ≈øome Sparks of Light, how will it ≈øhine when poli≈øh'd! If the Tree appears fair in the Verdure of its Leaves, will not the Blo≈ø≈øoms and Fruits make it look more lovely!
Speaking of Trees, minds me of two Lines in Virgil, which ≈øeems applicable to this Subject.
Exuarint Sylve≈øtrem animum, Cultuque frequenti, In qua≈øeunque voces Artes, hand tarda ≈øequentur.

p.hi: The ≈øavage Mind, by Culture when ≈øubdu'd, Will with the nobler Arts be ≈øoon imbu'd.

div.p: But there is no Occa≈øion for Virgil's Skill in grafting to prolong this Di≈øcour≈øe. ‚Äî Perhaps it is too tedious, I would not multiply Words.

My reading Mr. Colden, and tran≈øcribing the Indian Songs, rais'd the≈øe Thoughts in me. I imagin'd, that communicating them might be of Service. It is rot for me to proceed any further: If what is written ≈øeems for the Good of the Publick; the Ways and Means; the proper Method,‚Äîthat lies before others.

It may be, at the next A≈ø≈øembly, if it ≈øhall ≈øeem good to them; a Committee will be appointed to enquire into the State of the Indian Nations, and into the be≈øt Methods for pre≈øerving, and ≈øtrengthening, and improving our Alliance with them.

Perhaps, ≈øome will ≈øay, ≈øuch Cares ≈øhould begin at Home; that it becomes them chiefly to provide for the Education of their own Youth; and that they are to con≈øider of erecting and endowing a ≈øtately Edifice ≈øuitable to that Purpo≈øe.‚ÄîIt is very well,‚Äîwherefore ≈øhould they not?‚Äî But it is noble to have exten≈øive Views; That they may do; and yet not leave the other unders. They may look to the Welfare of their
Families, and to the Honour and Advantage of the Province.‚Äî Wherefore ≈øhould they not?‚Äî For this they have Dwellings in the≈øe Lands, and Seats in that Council.
But, at the ≈øame Time, they may comprehend, and deliberate on the promoting, more largely the Briti≈øh Intere≈øt, and the Cau≈øe of Humanity, of Chri≈øtianity.

This would give a peculiar Lu≈øtre to their A≈ø≈øembly. This would be to ri≈øe Forts and Bulwarks on their Borders. This would be to make their Province and City, a Name and a Prai≈øe on the Earth.‚Äî This would be indeed, more fully, to entitle them to the dear Appellations of Fathers and Patriots.
